Award.AwardTitle: Planning IUCRC at University of Tennessee/Knoxville: Center for [Digital Composite Joining and Repair]
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports a planning workshop for an Industry-University Cooperative Research Center (IUCRC) aimed at improving composite material joining and repair (CJAR) technologies. Composite materials are vital to the competitiveness of several sectors, including automotive, manufacturing, energy, biomedical, defense and aerospace. Current CJAR practices are highly specialized, labor-intensive, and require experienced technicians for critical inspection, maintenance and repair. Partner institutions including The University of Tennessee-Knoxville, Georgia Institute of Technology and Oakland University will collaborate with various industrial companies, in the automotive, aerospace, defense, energy, and biomedical sectors of the US economy. The University of Tennessee site of D-CJAR will engage the Institute for Advanced Composites Manufacturing Innovation (IACMI), Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ONR) - (Manufacturing Demonstration Facility (MDF) and Carbon Fiber Technology Facility (CFTF)), material suppliers, equipment manufacturers and end users. Examples include Magnum Venus Products (MVP), Resource Fiber, Mini-Fibers, HTS IC among others. Faculty and student teams at the partner universities will work with industry members to conduct pre-competitive research to develop and disseminate basic and applied technologies/knowledge to facilitate rapid, reliable, and cost-effective composite joining and repair, with an overall goal of significantly reducing costs, cycle time, and variation of CJAR operations within ten (10) years.

With the goal of transforming the current labor-intensive and specialized processes into science-based, automated, and digital CJAR processes, the University of Tennessee site of D-CJAR will primarily focus on developing CJAR technologies for multi-material joining and repair of advanced composites, metals and hybrids. We expect advances in several fields and knowledge domains around CJAR, including (1) design and analysis of multi-materials joining, (2) process innovations, (3) materials and process engineering, and (4) testing and nondestructive evaluation (NDE). We will apply advanced digital techniques, including advanced computational modeling, sensing, materials characterization, and machine learning to practical CJAR cases that will also advance the education and workforce preparedness of students working on projects at the partner universities. Development of new materials and processes would facilitate standardization, modeling, and automation of many CJAR tasks and processes, producing cost savings, faster cycle times, and enhanced performance for industry partners across the entire composites supply chain, contributing to the maintenance of U.S. global leadership in this growing sector.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF Grant award to University of Tennessee supported a planning workshop for a new Industry-University Cooperative Research Center (IUCRC) for Digital Composite Joining and Repair (D-CJAR) site with an Automotive-thrust, in close collaboration with Georgia Tech and the Oakland University, for a respective site of D-CJAR: one with Aerospace-thrust at GT and another with Automotive and related technologies at Oakland University. 

Subsequent to grant award University of Tennessee has accomplished the following tasks

 

Task 1:             Dr. Uday Vaidya (PI)  travelled from Knoxville to attend Bootcamp training at

                        NSF headquarters in Alexandria, VA, on Oct.29-30, 2018.

 

Task 2:             Subsequent to receiving NSF Bootcamp training, the PI and Co-Is (Dayakar Penumadu, Dibyendu Mukherjee and Elizabeth Barker) engaged 35 industrial constituents in a documented extensive customer discovery process over 90 days.  The process led to the development of a viable value proposition of interest to the automotive, industrial sectors. Material suppliers, recycling companies, carbon fiber technology, biomedical companies and related were integral to this exercise.

 

  • Out of the 35 companies who participated in the UT Customer discovery effort, 10 industrial delegates have travelled as part of the Oakland University contingency that participated in the March 5-6, 2019 NSF Planning meeting/workshop at Georgia Tech in Atlanta, GA.

 

  • Participated with GT and Oakland University in planning and conducting the March 5-6, 2019 NSF Planning meeting as follows:

 

-       Developed agenda in collaboration with GA Tech and Oakland University, led UT key faculty researchers (4 researchers), students (8 students), industry (12 industry partners) to the meeting. The12 industry partners represented cross-section of the composites industry. invitees from UT attended this meeting.

-       Developed and presented comprehensive research projects to the  wider industrial participants, NSF program director and personnel, and external program monitor.  

-       Responded to, and incorporated LIFE input at the Planning meeting.

 

Task 3:             Subsequent to the NSF Planning meeting on March 5-6, 2019 and LIFE input, grant PI

                        Co-Is have accomplished the following tasks:

 

-       April 2019:  Developed and submitted on Pre-proposal to NSF for Phase 1 of IUCRC D-CJAR site at University of Tennessee

 

-       May-June 2019: Secured financial commitment from 6 companies towards NSF-mandated Industrial Advisory Board (IAB)

 

-       June 2019:  Developed and submitted Phase 1 Proposal to NSF for an IUCRC D-CJAR site at University of Tennessee, in close coordination with partnering universities (GT and Oakland University), who independently submitted Phase 1 proposals for their respective sites of D-CJAR.

 

Budget Expenditure:

 

Total grant amount ($15,000 including Indirect cost) was as follows

 

$3,200 Junior faculty for customer discovery related salary support (Dibyendu Mukherjee, Elizabeth Barker) and administrator support (Vanina Ghossein)

 

$ 1,400   Travel to NSF for bootcamp training for Uday Vaidya (PI)

 

$3,600 Travel to NSF Planning meeting at Georgia Tech (personnel named below)*

 

$1,867 Customer discovery engagement and travel

 

$4,933 Indirect Cost charges  

_______________

$15,000     Total Budget

 

 

*Travel to planning meeting

Uday Vaidya (PI)

Dayakar Penumadu (Co-I)

Dibyendu Mukherjee (Co-I)

Elizabeth Barker (I)

Ahmed Hassen (I)

8 graduate students (Phillip Barnett, Shailesh Alwekar, Surbhi Kore, Ryan Spencer, Stephen Andrew, Nitilaksha Hiremath, Vidyarani Sangal, Hannah Maeser), administrator (Vanina Ghossein). The graduate students presented posters on their work in the evening hours of March 05.

Modified by: Uday K Vaidya

Subsequent to grant award University of Tennessee has accomplished the following tasks Task 1: Dr. Uday Vaidya (PI) travelled from Knoxville to attend Bootcamp training at NSF headquarters in Alexandria, VA, on Oct.29-30, 2018.
